title: ₹ 30 sells 32 orange in which a person has 25% loss, accordingly, how many oranges should be sold in ₹ 24 so that it can benefit 20% in this deal? - Quora

response.answer_text: Friends…! Profit/Loss = (Sale Price - Cost)/Cost By selling 32 orange for ₹ 30 a man loses 25% Loss = - 25/100 =- 0.25 Sale price = ₹30 Given loss of 25%, can be written as -0.25 = (30 - C)/C Cross multiplication -0.25C = 30 - C C - 0.25C = 30 0.75C = 30 C = 40 Cost price for 32 oranges is ₹40 32 Oranges Cost ₹40 Hence, each orange cost = 40/32 = ₹ 1.25 Let number of oranges required for Profit of 20% be x (24 - 1.25 × x)/1.25 × x = 0.20 24 - 1.25x = 0.20 (1.25x) 24 - 1.25x = 0.25x 24 = 0.25x + 1.25x 1.50x = 24 x = 24/1.50 x = 16 Therefore 16 oranges should be sold for ₹24 so as to gain a profit of 20% in the transaction. Answer 16 oranges should be sold for ₹24 so as to gain a profit of 20% in the transaction.

Firstly, the question is not clear. Because I am in confusion wheather the price of each orange is Rs 30 or the whole lot of 32 oranges are sold in Rs 30. I am solving the above question by considering selling price of indivisual orange is Rs 30. So total revenue from 32 oranges will be 32*30 = 960(In which he is incurring a loss of 25%) So Rs 960 will be 75% of total cost Total cost = (100/75)* 960 = 1280 If the seller wants to make a benefit of 20%, his total revenue should be 20% more than total cost. Total revenue= 1280 + (20/100) * 1280 = 1536 If he sells orange Rs 24 each, The number of orange he needs to sell is 1536/24 = 64 So, answer is 64. Hope the answer will be satisfactory. Thank you
